title: Hidden Pairs
description: When two digits only appear as candidates in two cells of a house, all other candidates can be removed from those cells.

steps.title: What are Hidden Pairs?
steps.content: A Hidden Pair occurs when two digits appear as candidates in exactly the same two cells within a house, and nowhere else in that house. Even though those cells may have other candidates, the pair is 'hidden' among them.

steps.title: Naked vs. Hidden Pairs
steps.content: In a Naked Pair, the two cells contain only the pair digits. In a Hidden Pair, the cells may have additional candidates — but the two key digits only appear in those two cells within the house.

steps.title: Find the hidden pair
steps.content: Look at the center box. Four cells are empty, but the digits 4 and 8 can only go in the two highlighted cells. The other two empty cells in the box can't hold 4 or 8 because both digits already appear in their row.

steps.title: The deduction
steps.content: Since 4 and 8 can only go in these two cells within the box, those two cells must contain 4 and 8. This means all other candidates in those two cells can be safely removed.

steps.title: Clean up the candidates
steps.content: Remove every candidate except 4 and 8 from the two highlighted cells. This effectively turns the Hidden Pair into a Naked Pair, which may trigger further eliminations in intersecting rows and columns.

steps.title: Searching for Hidden Pairs
steps.content: For each house, count how many cells contain each digit as a candidate. If two digits each appear in exactly the same two cells (and only those cells), you have a Hidden Pair.

steps.title: Why they're harder to spot
steps.content: Hidden Pairs are trickier than Naked Pairs because the key digits are buried among other candidates. The cells might have 3, 4, or even 5 candidates — you need to focus on where specific digits can go, not on the total candidate count.

steps.title: Practice tip
steps.content: When scanning for Hidden Pairs, pick two digits and check if they share the same two cells in any house. Systematic scanning digit-by-digit is slower but more reliable than trying to spot patterns visually.
